data.title: Gospel Music L
data.meta_description: FEATURING GEORGIA MUSIC ARTISTS, SONGWRITERS, PRODUCERS, MUSICIANS
data.text:
The LeFevres, (Atlanta, GA) was a Christian Southern Gospel group who performed for more than 50 years. As the new medium of television became more popular, the group started appearing on local stations such as WAGA and traveled to other regional stations to appear on their programs as well. In the 1960s, the group's Gospel Singing Caravan, a syndicated program, was aired nationwide. In addition to this, the group toured relentlessly in the U.S. and Canada, notching as many as 250 shows a year.

Since 1921, the LeFevre name has always been a leader in Gospel Music. Today, the name is stronger than ever. The LeFevre Quartet from Atlanta, GA formed in 2005 and within only a year, Gospel Music fans voted The LeFevre Quartet 2006's Singing News Fan Awards Horizon Group of The Year. In 2009, their song, “Big Mighty God” was nominated for a Dove Award. In 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019, The LeFevre Quartet was nominated as a Top 10 Traditional Quartet in the Singing News Magazine’s Fan Awards.

Darlene McCoy is a Christian gospel singer songwriter and soul R & B recording artist from Atlanta, GA. She was nominated for Urban Album of the Year at the 39th GMA Dove Awards. "I Shall Live And Not Die" released in 2011 peaked at #22 on the Billboard Gospel Songs chart.

Devin McGlamery is a Christian musician and a GMA Dove Award-winning artist. The Valdosta, GA native is a former tenor member of Karen Peck and New River and former lead vocalist for the Dixie Melody Boys and Ernie Haase and Signature Sound. He released "Love is a Verb", a studio album, in 2013 with Stow Town Records.

Danetra Moore is a Christian gospel singer songwriter residing in Atlanta, GA since 2004. She released her debut album in 2015, Light In The Dark which peaked at #22 on the Billboard Gospel Songs chart. She wrote the single "All I Can Do Is Pray" when she was only 15.

Doug Pittman is a Christian gospel music singer. Doug is 30 years old and originally from the small town of Eastman, Georgia. Doug has performed both nationally and internationally, including a United Kingdom tour in 2007 and his Carnegie Hall debut in 2010. Doug studied both Voice and Piano at Brewton-Parker College in Mount Vernon, Georgia. Doug began his professional Southern Gospel career in 2014 when he joined Ed O’Neal and the legendary Dixie Melody Boys

In 1946, singer James Sego formed a singing group with his brothers Lamar and Walter "W.R." called “The Harmony Kings”, before settling on the name “The Sego Brothers.” Naomi Easter met James Sego in 1948. They were married in 1949 and had two sons, James Carlton and Ronnie. Naomi would join the group after a member fell ill and their name was changed to Sego Brothers & Naomi. Naomi Sego was featured on The Sego Brother’s first album with the song Is My Lord Satisfied With Me. The album sold more than 300,000 copies. The Sego Brothers and Naomi was the first Southern Gospel Group to sell over a million records with the song "Sorry, I Never Knew You in 1964".

Aaron Shust, from Duluth, GA, is a Christian gospel music singer songwriter. He was awarded three Dove Awards: Song of the Year ("My Savior, My God"), Songwriter of the Year, and New Artist of the Year. The song " My Savior, My God" peaked at #1 on six Christian music charts including Billboard.

The Sunshine Boys of Macon, GA were a Christian gospel quartet. The group recorded over 800 songs during their career. Their release of "Peace In The Valley" written by another Georgian, Thomas A. Dorsey, sold over 1 million copies. The Sunshine Boys performed at The Golden Nugget on the strip in Las Vegas. Such accolades were due not only to their ability to sing spiritual quartet music with expertise, but also their versatility in performing country, western, pop, and jazz music as well. They were inducted into The Georgia Music Hall of Fame in 2005.

The Statesmen Quartet were founded in Atlanta, GA in 1948 by Hovie Lister. The Statesmen were the first southern gospel group to have a nationally syndicated program on television, Singing Time In Dixie dominating the southern gospel music for two decades. The group retired in 2002. They were inducted into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame in 1998.

Third Day is a Christian Contemporary gospel group formed in Marietta, GA. The band was inducted in the Georgia Music Hall of Fame on September 19, 2009. They have sold over 7 million albums in the United States and had 28 number one Christian album chart radio hits.
